description: From Middle English sith (“journey, movement, lifetime, period, occasion”), from Old English sīþ (“journey, movement, trip, point in time, occasion”), from Proto-West Germanic *sinþ, from Proto-Germanic *sinþaz, from Proto-Indo-European *sent- (“to go, head”). Cognate with Faroese sinn (“time”), Gothic 𐍃𐌹𐌽𐌸𐍃 (sinþs, “path, movement”), Icelandic sinn (“time”). See also send.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) One's journey of life, experience, one's lot, also by extension life, lifetime.
examples: Christ's sith of sorrow and suffering.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) An instant in time, a point in time or an occasion.

description: Clipping of sithen; compare German seit (“since”).
